tn.text: Ezekiel continues to tell about the vision that started in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:08:01|8:1]].
"which faces east." The "eastern gate" faced east.
The word "behold" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows.
Translate these words in the same way you did in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:08:16|8:16]].
"among the twenty-five men"
Ezekiel continues to tell about the vision.
"Son of a human being" or "Son of humanity." God calls Ezekiel this to emphasize that Ezekiel is only a human being. God is powerful and lives forever, but people are not. "Mortal person" or "Human"

tn.ref: this city is the pot, and we are the meat
tn.text: The people speak of themselves as if they were good cuts of meat and of the city as if it were a pot in which the meat was stored or cooked. The metaphor suggests that they are important and safe within the city. AT: "This city is like a pot that will protect us as a pot protects meat." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Possible meanings are 1) a pot for storing meat or 2) a pot for cooking meat.
Yahweh continues to talk to the prophet Ezekiel.

tn.ref: the Spirit of Yahweh fell on me
tn.text: Ezekiel speaks of the Spirit of Yahweh inspiring and empowering him to prophesy as if the Spirit of Yahweh fell upon him. AT: "the Spirit of Yahweh empowered me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The word "house" is a metonym for the family, in this case the Israelites who are the descendants of Jacob. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:03:01|3:1]]. AT: "people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"You are saying these things." This refers to what the people were saying in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:11:02|11:3]].

tn.ref: The people you have killed ... are the meat, and this city is the pot
tn.text: Yahweh speaks of the people whom they have killed as if they were good cuts of meat and of the city as if it were a pot in which the meat was stored or cooked. See how you translated this metaphor in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:11:02|11:3]]. AT: "The people you have killed ... are like the meat in the pot, and this city is the pot. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: But you are going to be brought out
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "But I am going to bring you out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Yahweh continues giving Ezekiel his message to Israel.

tn.ref: You have feared the sword, so I am bringing the sword upon you
tn.text: The word "sword" is a metonym for enemy armies who will attack with their swords. AT: "You have feared war, so I am bringing enemy armies to attack you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: put you into the hands of foreigners
tn.text: Here the word "hands" here represents power or control. AT: "I will put you into the power of foreigners" or "I will enable foreigners capture you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: You will fall by the sword
tn.text: The word "sword" is a metonym for enemy armies who will attack with their swords. To "fall by the sword" means that they will be killed with swords. AT: "They will kill you with their swords" (UDB) or "You will die in battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: you will know that I am Yahweh
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "you will understand who I, Yahweh, am" or 2) "you will understand that I am Yahweh, the one true God" or 3) "you will know that I, Yahweh, have the power to do the things that I say that I will do" (UDB). See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:06:06|6:7]]
Yahweh continues giving Ezekiel his message to Israel.

tn.ref: This city will not be your cooking pot, nor will you be the meat
tn.text: See note in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:11:02|11:3]].
This expression uses the borders to represent Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
the outer edges of a country or territory

tn.ref: will know that I am Yahweh
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:06:06|6:7]]
This phrase is used here to mark an important event in the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.
He was one of the wicked leaders of Israel mentioned in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:11:01|11:1]].
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:01:27|1:28]].
Ezekiel says this to show his fear about what will happen to the rest of the people there.
"Yahweh spoke his word." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:01:01|1:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is stated twice for emphasis.
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:03:01|3:1]].

tn.ref: All of them are those of whom it is said by those living in Jerusalem
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "All of them are those about whom the people living in Jerusalem are saying" or "The people living in Jerusalem say about all of them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: All of them are those of whom it is said
tn.text: Some modern versions have "All of them are those to whom it was said."
Yahweh gives Ezekiel his message to Israel about those who were scattered.

tn.ref: I have been a sanctuary for them
tn.text: AT: "I have been with them to preserve them."
AT: "nations where they have been taken"

tn.ref: I will gather you from the peoples, and assemble you from the lands
tn.text: Yahweh says this promise two times in different ways in order to show that it's important. AT: "I will bring you back from the nations of people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
AT: "horrible," or "offensive"
God continues the prophecy of what will happen to the scattered Israelites.

tn.ref: the stone heart from their flesh
tn.text: This is a way of saying that God will change their attitude from stubborn rebellion. AT: "their stubbornness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is a way to say that God will change their attitude to accept his rule. AT: "a willingness to obey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: they will walk in my statutes, they will carry out my decrees and do them
tn.text: Each of these phrases describes the people as obeying what Yahweh has commanded them to do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
AT: "devotion"
AT: "obnoxious things" or "offensive things"
AT: "actions"
AT: "back onto those people." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
AT: "statement"
The cherubim of Chapter 10 leave the temple and city along with the glory of God.
